title-group.article-title: Structureborne Contribution to Interior Noise of Propeller Aircraft

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1984 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: Measurements obtained for ground tests on a Twin Otter aircraft show that structureborne noise is a major contributor to the interior noise level. The structureborne source was the propeller blade wake and tip vortex interaction with the wing and contributes at the blade passage frequency and its harmonics.

ref.mixed-citation: F. B. Metzger, "Strategies for Aircraft Interior Noise Reduction in Existing and Future Propeller Aircraft." SAE paper 810560.
J. F. Dugan, B. A. Miller, E. J. Graber, and D. A. Sagerser, "The NASA High-Speed Turbo- prop Program." NASA TM 81561 and SAE Paper 801120, October 1980.

D. C. Rennison, J. F. Wilby, A. H. Marsh, and E. G. Wilby, "Interior Noise Control Prediction Study for High-Speed Propeller-Driven Aircraft." Bolt Beranek and Newman, Inc., BBN-4026, September 1979 (NASA CR-159200).

J. D. Revell, F. J. Balens, and L. R. Koval, "Analytical Study of Interior Noise Control by Fuselage Design Techniques on High- Speed, Propeller-Driven Aircraft." Lockheed- California Company, LR-29382, July 1978 (NASA CR-159222).
B. A. Miller, J. H. Dittmar, and R. J. Jeracki, "The Propeller Tip Vortex -A Possible Contributor to Aircraft Cabin Noise." NASA TM 81768, April 1981.
J. F. Unruh, D. C. Scheidt, and D. J. Pomerening, "Engine Induced Structural-Borne Noise in a General Aviation Aircraft." NASA CR 159099, August 1979.
M. McGary, "A New Measurement Method for Separating Airborne and Structureborne Noise Radiated by Aircraft-Type Panels." NASA TP 2079, September 1982.
